nodes.title: What Are The Parameters of The around Method in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: In Magento 2, plugins, also known as interceptors, are used to modify the behavior of class methods without having to extend or modify the original class. One such method is the around method, which allows for intercepting calls to a specific method and adding custom functionality before and/or after the original method is executed. The … Read more
nodes.content:
In Magento 2, plugins, also known as interceptors, are used to modify the behavior of class methods without having to extend or modify the original class. One such method is the around method, which allows for intercepting calls to a specific method and adding custom functionality before and/or after the original method is executed. The parameters of the around method in Magento 2 include the class and method being intercepted, as well as a closure that contains the custom functionality to be added. This allows for a more flexible and modular architecture, as well as the ability to add custom functionality without affecting the core codebase. One key question that developers may have is What are the Parameters of The around Method in Magento 2?

One of the methods that can be used in a plugin class is the around method. This method allows you to “wrap” a class method and execute your own code before and/or after the original method. In this way, you can modify the input and output of the method, or add additional functionality without having to change the original class. If you’re working with Magento 2, you might be interested in learning about the Magento 2 parameters of the around method or the specific parameters used in the around method of Magento 2 Parameters.

What Are The Parameters of The around Method in Magento 2: A Guide

The around Method Takes Two Parameters:

1.MagentoFrameworkInterceptionInterceptor $subject: 

This is the class that contains the method being intercepted. This parameter is passed automatically by the Magento framework, and you can use it to access other methods and properties of the class.

2.Closure $proceed: 

This is a closure (an anonymous function) that represents the original method. You can call this closure to execute the original method. The closure takes the same parameters as the original method and returns the same value.

3.$request:

 The parameter passed to the method being intercepted.

Here’s an example of an around method that modifies the behavior of a class method:

class MyPlugin

{

    public function aroundMyMethod(

        MagentoFrameworkInterceptionInterceptor $subject,

        Closure $proceed,

        $request

    ) {

        // Execute some code before the original method

        $modifiedRequest = $request . ' modified';

        // Execute the original method

        $result = $proceed($modifiedRequest);

        // Execute some code after the original method

        $modifiedResult = $result . ' modified';

        return $modifiedResult;

    }

}

In this example, the plugin class has an around method that intercepts a class method called method. The method takes a single parameter called $request. If you’re wondering what are the parameters of the around method in Magento 2, you might be interested to know that in this example, the $proceed closure is used to call the original method with the modified $request parameter. Before the original method is executed, the plugin code modifies the $request parameter by appending the string ” modified” to it. Then, it calls the original method by calling the $proceed closure with the modified parameter. After the original method is executed, the plugin code modifies the result by appending the string ” modified” to it. Finally, it returns the modified result.

It’s important to note that around method should return the result of the original method or a modified version of it.

Conclusion

In summary, the around method in Magento 2 provides a powerful way to modify the behavior of class methods without having to modify the original class. It allows you to add custom functionality and make changes to the input and output of the method, while still preserving the original functionality. If you’re wondering what are the parameters of the around method in Magento 2, it’s worth noting that they can vary depending on the method being intercepted. This helps to keep the codebase clean, maintainable, and easy to extend. Additionally, How to Setup Magento 2 is a useful guide for those who are looking to set up and configure their Magento 2 e-commerce platform.

nodes.title: How Many types of Dependency Injection in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: How Many Types of Dependency Injection in Magento 2 and How it is Used in Magento 2: Automatic Dependency Injection (ADI) eliminates the need for an object to search for its dependent objects. There are three types of ADI: Constructor Injection, Setter Injection, and Interface Injection. Magento 2 uses ADI, specifically Constructor Injection, where dependencies … Read more
nodes.content:
How Many Types of Dependency Injection in Magento 2 and How it is Used in Magento 2: Automatic Dependency Injection (ADI) eliminates the need for an object to search for its dependent objects. There are three types of ADI: Constructor Injection, Setter Injection, and Interface Injection. Magento 2 uses ADI, specifically Constructor Injection, where dependencies are passed as parameters in the constructor to adhere to injection rules. This method is an alternative to the Mage Class method used in Magento 1. An example in Magento 2 is provided to illustrate this concept.

A Complete Guide to Types of Dependency Injection in Magento 2

The Helper Class in Magento 2, Data.php, is defined as follows:

namespace Namespace\Module\Helper;

class Data extends \Magento\Framework\App\Helper\AbstractHelper

{

    public function HelperFunc()

    {

        return 1;

    }

}

The HelperFunc() method can be called using Dependency Injection (DI) in the following way:

class ClassName

{

    public function __construct(\Namespace\Module\Helper\Data $helper)

    {

        $this->helper = $helper;

    }

    public function func()

    {

        $this->helper->HelperFunc();

    }

}

In the above code, the Dependency is injected into the constructor of the ClassName class. This method, which involves dependency injection in Magento 2, can be used throughout Magento 2 and is a powerful way to manage dependencies and decouple components.

Why Magento 2 Dependency Injection is Preferred Over Object Manager?

While the Object Manager in Magento 2 can instantiate objects and inject dependencies through its create() method and instance configuration files, it is not recommended to use it. If you’re wondering how many types of dependency injection in Magento 2 are available, it’s worth noting that Magento 2 supports three types of dependency injection: constructor injection, setter injection, and property injection. Using the Object Manager defeats the purpose of Dependency Injection, as it does not follow Magento 2’s development processes and can create hidden dependencies. It may be used in some parts of the core, but it is expected to be refactored in the future. Adhering to Magento 2’s preferred method of dependency management leads to a cleaner and more organized codebase, better performance, and improved scalability.

Also Read: How to Configure a Cron Job in Magento 2

Conclusion

In conclusion, adhering to established code patterns is crucial when developing Magento 2. The Magento community strongly recommends using Magento 2’s Dependency Injection over the Object Manager. This article provided a brief introduction to Automatic Dependency Injection, Constructor Injection, and the Object Manager in Magento 2. If you’re wondering how many types of dependency injection in Magento 2 are available, It’s worth noting that Magento 2 supports three types of injection: constructor injection, setter injection, and property injection. Additionally, it highlighted the importance of understanding the different types of injection in Magento 2. There is much more to learn about each topic in depth. Keep an eye out for more information and resources. If you have any questions, feel free to ask in the comments section and I will respond.

Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.

nodes.title: How to Install Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Installing Magento 2 can be a challenge for those who are new to e-commerce, but with the right guidance, it can be done with ease. The first step in installing Magento 2 is to make sure that your system meets the minimum requirements for installation then afterwards you can setup Magento 2. This includes having … Read more
nodes.content:
Installing Magento 2 can be a challenge for those who are new to e-commerce, but with the right guidance, it can be done with ease. The first step in installing Magento 2 is to make sure that your system meets the minimum requirements for installation then afterwards you can setup Magento 2. This includes having a web server, PHP, and a database. Before starting the installation process, it’s important to ensure that your system is up to date and ready to handle Magento 2.Here is a step-by-step guide on how to install Magento 2:

Steps to Install Magento 2

Step 1: Install Prerequisites

Before installing Magento 2, make sure your system meets the following requirements:

PHP 7.4.x or 7.3.x (with the required extensions)

MySQL 5.7 or 8.0 (or MariaDB equivalent)

Apache 2.4 or Nginx 1.x (or another compatible web server)

Composer

To install these prerequisites on Ubuntu, you can use the following commands:

python

sudo apt update
sudo apt install apache2 mysql-server php7.4 php7.4-cli php7.4-mysql php7.4-curl php7.4-intl php7.4-mbstring php7.4-gd php7.4-xsl php7.4-zip php7.4-soap composer

Note: Make sure to replace php7.4 with php7.3 if you prefer to use PHP 7.3 instead of 7.4.

Step 2: Download Magento 2

Create a directory for your Magento 2 installation and navigate to it using the following commands:

bash 

mkdir ~/magento2

cd ~/magento2

Next, download the Magento 2 installation files using the following command:

This will download the latest version of Magento 2 Community Edition and install it in the current directory.

Step 3: Set File Permissions

Magento 2 requires some specific file permissions. To set them, run the following commands:

bash

sudo chown -R www-data:www-data .

sudo find . -type f -exec chmod 644 {} ;

sudo find . -type d -exec chmod 755 {} ;

sudo chmod -R 777 var/ pub/ generated/

Step 4: Configure the Database

Create a new MySQL database and user for your Magento 2 installation using the following commands:

css

sudo mysql -u root -p

Enter your MySQL root password when prompted, then run the following commands to create a new database and user:

sql

CREATE DATABASE magento2;

GRANT ALL ON magento2.* TO 'magento2user'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';

FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

EXIT;

Note: Make sure to replace password with a strong password of your choice.

Step 5: Install Magento 2

Finally, you can install Magento 2 by running the following command:

arduino

php bin/magento setup:install 

--base-url=http://localhost 

--db-host=localhost 

--db-name=magento2 

--db-user=magento2user 

--db-password=password 

--admin-firstname=Admin 

--admin-lastname=User 

--admin-email=admin@example.com 

--admin-user=admin 

--admin-password=admin123 

--language=en_US 

--currency=USD 

--timezone=America/Chicago 

--use-rewrites=1 

--backend-frontname=admin

Note: Make sure to replace password with the password you set for your MySQL user in step 4, and adjust the other options to your liking.

Once the installation is complete, you can access your new Magento 2 store by navigating to http://localhost/ in your web browser.

Conclusion

Installing Magento 2 is a complex process that involves multiple steps and requires careful attention to detail. By following the steps described in this guide, you can set up a fully functional online store in a short period of time. Remember that Magento 2 is a robust e-commerce platform, and taking the time to prepare adequately and exercise patience will go a long way in guaranteeing a successful installation.

Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.

nodes.title: How to Create a Declarative Schema in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 uses a declarative schema to define the structure of the database tables and the relationships between them. This approach allows developers to describe the desired state of the database, and Magento will automatically make the necessary changes to bring the database into compliance with the schema. By using a declarative schema, developers can … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 uses a declarative schema to define the structure of the database tables and the relationships between them. This approach allows developers to describe the desired state of the database, and Magento will automatically make the necessary changes to bring the database into compliance with the schema. By using a declarative schema, developers can simplify database management and reduce the risk of errors when making changes to the database structure. In this tutorial, we will guide you through the process of creating a declarative schema in Magento 2, including defining tables, columns, and relationships.

Magento 2 is an open-source e-commerce platform that uses the Magento Framework in PHP and provides developers with the ability to create custom modules with their own database schemas. Also php framework helps developers to not create repetitive codes. One way to define these schemas is by using the declarative schema, which is a new feature in Magento 2.3 and later. This article will provide a step-by-step guide on how to create a declarative schema in Magento 2.

Steps to Create a Declarative Schema in Magento 2

Step 1: Create the module structure

To start for How to Create a Declarative Schema in Magento 2, you need to create a basic module structure in your Magento 2 instance. You can use the following commands to create a new module:

vbnet
php bin/magento setup:module:create --name=Vendor_Module --namespace=Vendor --module-name=Module

Step 2: Create the database table

Next, create a database table by creating the db_schema.xml file in the etc directory of your module. This file defines the database table structure, including the columns and indexes. The following is an example of a simple db_schema.xml file:

xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<schema xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:framework:Setup/Declaration/Schema/etc/schema.xsd">

    <table name="module_example">

        <column xsi:type="int" name="id" padding="11" unsigned="true" nullable="false" identity="true" comment="ID"/>

        <column xsi:type="varchar" name="name" nullable="false" length="255" comment="Name"/>

        <column xsi:type="timestamp" name="created_at" nullable="false" default="CURRENT_TIMESTAMP" comment="Created At"/>

        <constraint xsi:type="primary" referenceId="PRIMARY">

            <column name="id"/>

        </constraint>

    </table>

</schema>

Step 3: Run the Upgrade Schema script

To apply the changes to the database, you need to run the UpgradeSchema script. To do this, create the UpgradeSchema.php file in the Setup directory of your module. The following is an example of a simple UpgradeSchema script:

php
<?php

namespace Vendor\Module\Setup;

use Magento\Framework\Setup\UpgradeSchemaInterface;

use Magento\Framework\Setup\ModuleContextInterface;

use Magento\Framework\Setup\SchemaSetupInterface;

class UpgradeSchema implements UpgradeSchemaInterface

{

    public function upgrade(SchemaSetupInterface $setup, ModuleContextInterface $context)

    {

        $setup->startSetup();

        if (version_compare($context->getVersion(), '1.0.1', '<')) {

            $setup->getConnection()->addColumn(

                $setup->getTable('module_example'),

                'description',

                [

                    'type' => \Magento\Framework\DB\Ddl\Table::TYPE_TEXT,

                    'nullable' => true,

                    'comment' => 'Description',

                ]

            );

        }

        $setup->endSetup();

    }

}

4: Update the module version

To trigger the UpgradeSchema script, you need to update the module version in the module.xml file located in the etc directory of your module. The following is an example of an updated module.xml file:

xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<config xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:framework:Module/etc/module.xsd">

    <module name="Vendor_Module" setup_version="1.0.1">

        <sequence>

            <module name="Magento_DeclarativeSchema"/>

        </sequence>

    </module>

</config>

Step 5: Deploy the module

Finally, to deploy the module, you need to run the following command:

python

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

This will apply the changes to the database, and you should now have a new table in your Magento 2 instance with the structure defined in your db_schema.xml file.

conclusion

In conclusion, the declarative schema in Magento 2 is a convenient way to define database tables, and the Upgrade Schema script makes it easy to apply changes to your database. By following the steps outlined in this article, you should now be able to create a declarative schema in Magento 2. Hope so the blog on how to create a declarative schema in Magento 2 was helpful to you.

Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.

nodes.title: How to Create Bundle Product in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: A bundle product indicates customizable product combination that you can build for your own. It is a package of two or more products that stand alone but sold together for a single cost. Items are based on such product types: Simple Product and Virtual Product, and you can set either dynamic or fixed value for … Read more
nodes.content:
A bundle product indicates customizable product combination that you can build for your own. It is a package of two or more products that stand alone but sold together for a single cost. Items are based on such product types: Simple Product and Virtual Product, and you can set either dynamic or fixed value for a bundle. Bundle products enable you to increase sales, clear inventories quickly, and provide customers with more completed solutions.

Creating a bundle product in Magento 2 is a great way to offer multiple products for a single price. Bundle products allow customers to select from a variety of options and customize their own product package. Bundles also include configurable products. If you want to create configurable product then read our detailed guide on how to create configurable product in Magento 2. Here’s a step-by-step guide on how to create a bundle product in Magento 2:

Steps to Create Bundle Product in Magento 2

STEP 1:

Log in to the Magento 2 admin panel and navigate to the Products menu.

STEP 2:

Click on the “Add Product” button to create a new product

STEP 3:

Select “Bundle Product” as the product type.

STEP 4:

Fill in the basic product information, such as the name, SKU, and price.

STEP 5:

Scroll down to the “Bundle Options” section. Here, you can add different options for the bundle product, such as different sizes or colors.

STEP 6:

Click on the “Add Option” button to add a new option. Give the option a name and select the input type (e.g. drop-down, checkbox, etc.).

STEP 7:

Under the “Selections” section, add the products that will be included in the bundle. You can add products by searching for them by name or SKU, or by selecting them from a list of all products.

STEP 8:

Set the quantity and user defined quantity for each product in the bundle, you can also set price for the product.

STEP 9:

Once you have added all the options and selections, scroll back up to the top of the page and click the “Save” button.

STEP 10:

Your bundle product is now created and can be found in the catalog.

Conclusion:

Bundle products can be a great way to increase sales and offer customers more options. With Magento 2, creating a bundle product is a simple process that can be done in just a few steps. In conclusion, Bundle products can be a great way to increase sales and offer customers more options. With Magento 2, creating a bundle product is a simple process that can be done in just a few steps. It’s an easy way to increase sales and give your customers more options, making it a great option for any business looking to expand their product offerings.

nodes.title: How to Install an Extension from Magento 2 Marketplace
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 Marketplace is a virtual marketplace that facilitates the installation of software extensions for e-commerce websites powered by Magento 2. An extension is a supplementary software component that adds advanced functionalities and features to a Magento 2 online store. Installing an extension from Magento 2 Marketplace is a quick and easy process that can … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 Marketplace is a virtual marketplace that facilitates the installation of software extensions for e-commerce websites powered by Magento 2. An extension is a supplementary software component that adds advanced functionalities and features to a Magento 2 online store. Installing an extension from Magento 2 Marketplace is a quick and easy process that can be executed in a few simple steps, akin to installing an extension in Magento 2. This article aims to offer a detailed guide on the steps involved in how to install an extension from Magento 2 Marketplace.

Steps to Install an Extension from Magento 2 Marketplace 

Step 1: Find the extension

Visit the Magento 2 Marketplace and search for the extension you want to install. Once you find it, click on the extension and review its features and requirements.

Step 2: Obtain the Access Keys

Before you can install an extension, you need to obtain your Magento Marketplace access keys. To get them, go to the Magento Marketplace and log in to your account. Next, go to My Profile > Access Keys, and then click Create A New Access Key. Fill in the required fields and save the key pair.

Step 3: Install the Composer

Composer is a package manager that enables you to download, install, and manage extensions from the Magento Marketplace. To install Composer, run the following commands in your terminal:

bash

cd ~

curl -sS https://getcomposer.org/installer | php

sudo mv composer.phar /usr/local/bin/compose

Step 4: Add the Extension to Composer

To add the extension to the composer, run the following command in your terminal:

bash
composer require vendor/extension-name

Replace the vendor/extension name with the actual vendor name and extension name.

Step 5: Install the Extension

After adding the extension to the composer, you can now install it using the following command:

arduino
php bin/magento setup:upgrade

This command upgrades your Magento instance and installs the new extension.

Step 6: Verify the Extension

After installation, verify that the extension is correctly installed by running the following command:

lua
php bin/magento module:status

This command lists all installed modules, including the new extension. If the extension is not listed, repeat the installation process.

Step 7: Refresh Cache

After the installation is complete, navigate to System > Cache Management and refresh the cache. Log out of the Magento 2 store’s admin panel and log back in to verify that the extension has been installed and is functioning properly.

Conclusion

Installing an extension from the Magento 2 Marketplace can be an excellent way to enhance the functionality of your Magento 2 store. The process itself is relatively simple and easy to follow, as detailed in this article. By taking these steps, you can easily install and begin using an extension from the Magento 2 Marketplace.

However, it’s always a good idea to be cautious when installing new software, and backing up your store’s database and files beforehand is highly recommended. This way, you can avoid losing any critical data in case something goes wrong during the installation process.

If you run into any issues or have any questions about the installation process, don’t hesitate to reach out to either the extension provider or Magento 2 support for assistance. They’ll be able to provide you with the necessary guidance to help you get your extension up and running smoothly.

Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.

nodes.title: How to Reindex in Magento 2 from Command Line
nodes.excerpt: Reindexing in Magento 2 is the process of updating the data in your store’s index to ensure that it is accurate and up-to-date. If you make changes to your store’s data, such as adding new products or updating existing ones, you will need to reindex to reflect those changes in your store’s search results and … Read more
nodes.content:
Reindexing in Magento 2 is the process of updating the data in your store’s index to ensure that it is accurate and up-to-date. If you make changes to your store’s data, such as adding new products or updating existing ones, you will need to reindex to reflect those changes in your store’s search results and catalog pages. There are 2 ways to reindex in magento 2 from the admin panel and other by command line. In this article, we will provide a detailed guide on how to reindex in Magento 2 from command line.

Steps to Reindex in Magento 2 from Command Line

Step 1: Connect to your Magento 2 server

The first step to reindexing in Magento 2 from the command line is to connect to your Magento 2 server. You can use a terminal or a command prompt to access your server.

Step 2: Navigate to the Magento 2 root directory

Once you are connected to your Magento 2 server, navigate to the root directory of your Magento 2 store. This is the directory that contains the “app”, “bin”, and “pub” directories.

Step 3: Run the Reindex Command

From the Magento 2 root directory, run the following command to reindex your store:

python
php bin/magento indexer:reindex

Step 4: Wait for the Reindexing Process to Complete

Wait for the reindexing process to complete. This may take a few minutes, depending on the size of your store’s data.

Step 5: Verify the Reindexing Process

After the reindexing process is complete, you can verify that the reindexing process was successful by running the following command:

python
php bin/magento indexer:info

This command will display the status of all the indexes in your store. The status of the reindexed indexes should be “Ready”.

Conclusion

Reindexing in Magento 2 is an important process that ensures the accuracy of your store’s data. By following the steps outlined in this article, you can easily reindex your Magento 2 store from the command line. If you experience any issues with the reindexing process, contact Magento 2 support for assistance. It is always a good idea to backup your store’s database and files before making any changes to your store, such as reindexing.

Please follow and like us:
Aaron Jenkins

I am Aaron Jenkins, a Magento Developer with over 12+ years of experience. I specialize in Magento 2 and I am passionate about sharing my knowledge and experience through my blog. Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.

nodes.title: How to Install Magento 2 Enterprise Edition
nodes.excerpt: It is essential to verify that your server meets the minimum system prerequisites for running Magento 2 Enterprise Edition before initiating the installation process. These requirements comprise elements like the PHP version, MySQL version, and web server software. Once you have confirmed that your server meets the criteria, you can proceed with the installation process. … Read more
nodes.content:
It is essential to verify that your server meets the minimum system prerequisites for running Magento 2 Enterprise Edition before initiating the installation process. These requirements comprise elements like the PHP version, MySQL version, and web server software.

Once you have confirmed that your server meets the criteria, you can proceed with the installation process. Even though installing Magento 2 Enterprise Edition may seem intimidating, with appropriate steps and preparation, it can be a simple process. In this article, we will discuss the process of how to install Magento 2 Enterprise Edition on a local development environment in detail.

Prerequisites

Before starting the installation process, make sure that you have the following:

  • A web server (Apache or Nginx)
  • PHP 7.2 or later
  • MySQL 5.6 or later
  • Composer
  • SSH access to your server

Step 1: Download Magento 2 Enterprise Edition

Next, download the Magento 2 Enterprise Edition installation package using the following command:

bash
wget <magento2-enterprise-edition-url>

Step 2: Extract the files

Once the download is complete, extract the files using the following command:

bash
tar -xzf <magento2-enterprise-edition-filename>.tar.gz

Step 3: Create a MySQL database

Create a new MySQL database and user for Magento 2 using the following commands:

bash

mysql -u root -p

CREATE DATABASE <database-name>;

GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON <database-name>.* TO '<username>'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY '<password>';

FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

Note: Replace <database-name>, <username>, and <password> with your desired values.

Step 4: Configure web server

Configure your web server to point to the Magento 2 installation directory. For example, if you are using Apache, you can create a new virtual host file using the following command:

bash
nano /etc/apache2/sites-available/magento2.conf

Add the following configuration to the file:

apache

<VirtualHost *:80>

    ServerName <your-domain>

    DocumentRoot /var/www/html/magento2

    <Directory /var/www/html/magento2>

        Options Indexes FollowSymLinks MultiViews

        AllowOverride All

        Order allow,deny

        allow from all

    </Directory>

    ErrorLog /var/log/apache2/magento2_error.log

    CustomLog /var/log/apache2/magento2_access.log combined

</VirtualHost>

Note: Replace <your-domain> with your domain name and /var/www/html/magento2 with the path to your Magento 2 installation directory.

Step 5: Install Magento 2

Run the Magento 2 installation wizard using the following command:

bash
php bin/magento setup:install --base-url=<your-domain> 

--db-host=<db-host> 

--db-name=<database-name> 

--db-user=<username> 

--db-password=<password> 

--admin-firstname=<admin-firstname> 

--admin-lastname=<admin-lastname> 

--admin-email=<admin-email> 

--admin-user=<admin-username> 

--admin-password=<admin-password> 

--backend-frontname=<backend-name>

Note: Replace the variables with your values. <db-host> should be set to localhost by default.

After installation, you can access the Magento 2 backend by navigating to http://<your-domain>/<backend-name>.

That’s it! You have successfully installed Magento 2 Enterprise Edition using commands. You can now configure your store settings, install extensions, and start selling products.

Conclusion:

Although the process of installing Magento 2 Enterprise Edition may appear overwhelming, it can be a hassle-free process with the proper steps and preparations. By adhering to the steps provided in this blog post, you can install Magento 2 Enterprise Edition seamlessly on your local development environment. It is essential to allocate sufficient time to personalize and configure your store to cater to your specific requirements. Additionally, you have the option to install magento 2.4 using composer.

Please follow and like us:
Aaron Jenkins

I am Aaron Jenkins, a Magento Developer with over 12+ years of experience. I specialize in Magento 2 and I am passionate about sharing my knowledge and experience through my blog. Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.

nodes.title: How to Install Extension in Magento 2 Manually
nodes.excerpt: Installing extensions in Magento 2 manually is a simple process that can be completed in just a few steps. Whether you’re looking to add new functionality to your online store or improve the overall user experience, installing extensions can be a great way to enhance your website. In this guide, we’ll walk you through the … Read more
nodes.content:
Installing extensions in Magento 2 manually is a simple process that can be completed in just a few steps. Whether you’re looking to add new functionality to your online store or improve the overall user experience, installing extensions can be a great way to enhance your website. In this guide, we’ll walk you through the process of manually installing extensions in Magento 2, so you can start taking advantage of the many features and tools available to you.

Magento Marketplace by Adobe Commerce offers multiple extensions from different providers to help grow your business. you can also install magento extensions if needed.

In this blog post, we will walk through the process of how to install extension in Magento 2 manually. 

Steps to Install Extension in Magento 2 Manually 

Step 1: Download the Extension

The first step for how to install extension in Magento 2 manually is to download the extension package. You can usually find extension packages on the Magento Marketplace or the developer’s website. Make sure to download the package that is compatible with your version of Magento 2.

Step 2: Unzip the Extension Package

Once you have downloaded the extension package, unzip it to a directory on your computer. This will reveal the extension’s files and folders.

Step 3: Upload the Extension to Your Magento 2 Installation

The next step is to upload the extension’s files and folders to your Magento 2 installation. To do this, connect to your Magento 2 installation using an FTP client such as FileZilla. Navigate to the “app/code” directory and create a new directory with the name of the extension’s company. Inside this directory, create another directory with the name of the extension. Now upload the extension’s files and folders to this directory.

Step 4: Enable the Extension

Now that the extension’s files are uploaded to your Magento 2 installation, you need to enable the extension. To do this, log into the Magento 2 admin panel and navigate to “Stores > Configuration > Advanced > Advanced”. Under the “Disable Modules Output” section, find the extension you just installed and click on the “Enable” button.

Step 5: Run the Setup Upgrade

The final step is to run the setup upgrade. This step is required to update the database and make the extension work properly. To do this, navigate to the root directory of your Magento 2 installation and run the following command:

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

After running this command, the extension should be successfully installed and enabled on your Magento 2 installation.

Note: In case of how to install extension in Magento 2 manually you are facing any issues with the above steps, you should check for the extension’s documentation for specific installation instructions or reach out to the developer for support.

Conclusion

In conclusion, how to install extension in Magento 2 manually is a straightforward process that can be easily completed by following the steps outlined in this guide. By taking the time to install extensions, you’ll be able to take full advantage of the many features and tools available to you and can improve the overall user experience of your online store. Keep in mind that installing extensions may require you to make changes to your website’s code, so it’s important to be familiar with Magento 2’s file structure and know how to properly modify the files.

Please follow and like us:
Aaron Jenkins

I am Aaron Jenkins, a Magento Developer with over 12+ years of experience. I specialize in Magento 2 and I am passionate about sharing my knowledge and experience through my blog. Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.

nodes.title: How to Install Magento 2 on AWS : (Amazon Web Services)
nodes.excerpt: Hello there, fellow readers! It brings me great joy to share with you some valuable insights on how to install Magento 2 on AWS! As you may already know, Magento is a robust open-source eCommerce platform that empowers businesses of all sizes to build and manage their online stores with ease. AWS, on the other … Read more
nodes.content:
Hello there, fellow readers! It brings me great joy to share with you some valuable insights on how to install Magento 2 on AWS! As you may already know, Magento is a robust open-source eCommerce platform that empowers businesses of all sizes to build and manage their online stores with ease. AWS, on the other hand, is a versatile cloud computing platform that provides a wide range of services and tools for effectively running applications and managing infrastructure.

For those who are new to the world of eCommerce and cloud computing, setting up Magento 2 on AWS can be a daunting and perplexing task. However, fear not! With the right guidance and support, this process can be as simple as possible. In this comprehensive guide, I’ll walk you through each step of the process, from setting up the required AWS resources, configuring the server, and ultimately installing Magento 2 itself.

Whether you’re an experienced developer, a small business owner, or simply an eCommerce enthusiast, this guide is designed to cater to your unique needs and requirements. By the end of this tutorial, you’ll have a fully functional Magento 2 installation up and running on AWS, ready for you to begin building and managing your online store like a pro!

Without further ado, let’s dive right in and uncover the secrets to successfully installing Magento 2 on AWS!

How to Install Magento 2 on AWS: A Step-by-Step Guide

Introducing Amazon Web Services :

Hey there, folks! Are you ready to embark on an exciting journey to set up your very own online store with Magento 2 on Amazon Web Services (AWS)? As a seasoned eCommerce developer and AWS aficionado, I’m thrilled to share with you my tried-and-true tips and tricks to make this process as seamless as possible.

First things first, let’s get familiar with Magento and AWS. Magento is a powerhouse open-source eCommerce platform that enables businesses of all sizes to create and manage online stores with ease. AWS, on the other hand, is a versatile cloud computing platform that offers a wide range of services and tools to run applications and manage infrastructure efficiently.

If you’re new to the world of eCommerce and cloud computing, don’t worry! I’ll walk you through each step of the process, from setting up the necessary AWS resources, configuring the server, and installing Magento 2 itself. By the end of this tutorial, you’ll have a fully functional Magento 2 installation up and running on AWS, ready for you to start building your online store like a pro!

Regardless of your experience level, this guide is designed to cater to your unique needs and requirements. Whether you’re an experienced developer, a small business owner, or an eCommerce enthusiast, you’ll find all the necessary information and guidance on how to setup Magento on Amazon AWS with ease.

So, let’s get started and uncover the secrets of how to install Magento 2 on AWS!

Let’s Get Started with Magento AWS hosting

1. Set up a server on Amazon:

First and foremost, you need to go to Amazon and set up an account. Next, you are required to navigate to the AWS management console, and you will see this:

In case, if you are unable to see it. Try searching for it in “Find services” and click on it. You will surely find this.

  • Click on Launch Instance
  • Select a machine with the default operating system (OS) such as Linux, Ubuntu, Windows, etc.

All you require doing is select the Ubuntu server. However, you can certainly choose Linux or windows as there is nothing wrong with choosing that. I personally prefer Ubuntu. The configurations are almost the same. Just make sure you match up with Magento 2 system requirements – 2G of RAM. But I personally advise having 4 GB RAM.

  • Select Type t2 medium
  • Click on Configure Instance details and you will see

It’s time to configure your machine. And fret not, there is nothing much to do here. Simply proceed further with adding storage options. By default storage size is enough though. But even if you want to increase then just increase the size.

Now it’s time to click on Add tags and try configuring the security group button. No matter how simpler it seems, it is very crucial though!

Adding the details comes next. It’s time to add rules about which people from across the globe will be able to access your server. Are you following a protocol? It’s time to make your server accessible to all traffic. Here, we can put security rules or try navigating the type and selecting all traffic. You can click anywhere you want.

Click review and launch. Then you will have the opportunity to review your configuration again. Click launch. You will see the following:

  • Now I am sure you must be wondering regarding the column, select key pair. Well, simply put a key that lets you connect to your server machine securely. Technically speaking, it comprises a public key that AWS stores and a private key file that you store. Together connections can be established in a secure manner. Download the key pair and keep it secure as without it you won’t be able to access your server. A new screen will be seen.
  • Now click New Instance and in the status check, you can see things getting initialized. Just forget about the old server and navigate to the empty space. Do you find notice a pencil write an icon? Simply click on it and name your server. Can you check your system status?
  • Lastly, as you are connected to a new server time to opt for an easy way. Here’s the time when you need to look for the key pair the one you downloaded earlier. I hope you must be having git installed. So select git bash here and copy this line.

Do not forget to paste it in git bash:

And we are done! Press enter and you will find it on your server.

2. Install Pre-requisite tools on the server:

Install PHP gd extension

apt-get install php7.2-gd

Now Restart the Apache:

systemctl restart apache2

And then navigate

cd /etc/apache2/

sudo nano apache2.conf

Press ctrl+w and search indexes

Now just install composer:

composer install

If you come across an error

Now you have to change the permissions of the folder so that Magento setup can install the required files:

chmod -R 755 /var/www/html/Magento2/

chmod -R 777 /var/www/html/Magento2/var/

chmod -R 777 /var/www/html/Magento2/pub/

chmod -R 777 /var/www/html/Magento2/app/etc

chmod -R 777 /var/www/html/Magento2/generated

sudo service Apache2 restart

Otherwise, the PHP extension will be missing.

3. Setup Database:

Log in to MySQL with this command

mysql -u root -p

It will ask you for a password. By default it’s none, so just press Enter. Now you are in the MySQL terminal.

show databases show you the current table.

create database Magento: it will create a database for Magento

exit: it will exit from MySQL terminal

4. Install and configure Magento on AWS:

Navigate to your public IP address and Copy and paste it into your browser like xx.xxx.xxx.xx/Magento2/setup

And you are all set to set up your Magento on AWS. And it’s time for you to install it.

Faster Way to Install Magento on AWS using Managed Magento Hosting

Because it can be done with just 1-click. Yes, all you have to do is just one click and Magento can be installed in the AWS cloud. However, you can also prefer to directly host but it might turn out to be quite challenging. After all, the SysAdmin-oriented functioning of Amazon is not everyone’s cup of tea. Here’s when cloudways comes in with its platform. Thus, I am sure now you will be able to easily and successfully launch pre-configured development software like Magento on the AWS cloud.

Performance:

Speaking in high regard to eCommerce stores, performance nowadays turns out to be of utmost importance. It seems like Amazon has invested hundreds, thousands, and even millions of dollars in their data centers to provide the best infrastructure to Magento owners. When combining Amazon and Magento, what you get is flawless integration on the cloudways platform. If simply put, faster load times and optimal performance on your Magento store are some of its perks that cannot be avoided.

Flexibility:

Another exciting feature of AWS on cloudways is its unimaginable flexibility. Incorporating cloudways to host your Magento on AWS means you are allowed to scale your server whenever there is a need. So basically, now you don’t have to worry in case if you find any sudden influx of traffic on your Magento store during the upcoming holiday season.

Pricing:

Of course, there was a time when pricing was given great importance but not as of now. Today, the pricing is more based on the pay-as-you-go model. When hosting Magento on AWS using cloudways, all you require doing is simply pay for the services you use. Also, you have this chance of familiarizing yourself with the console and test its capabilities without paying for the whole month or even the year. The most interesting part here is, there is no risk, no obligation, and no credit card required- you can back off anytime you want.

Other salient features include:

  • 24/7 tech support and server management
  • Optimized servers with an advanced caching mechanism
  • Dedicated IP’s
  • Ability to host multiple eCommerce stores with dedicated SSL protection on the same IP
  • Simple to manage Server and Application Control panel
  • Real-time performance monitoring
  • Server cloning scaling
  • Secure hosting
  • Automated offsite backups
  • Git, SSL, SSH, and Cron Job Managers
  • Addons for email, DNS, load testing, etc

How to integrate Amazon S3 Server into your Magento store?

To get started, the first step is creating an Amazon AWS account. For optimal results, consider using the Amazon S3 integration extension which allows for easy uploading and synchronization of your catalog images and downloadable products with Amazon S3. Once that’s done, connecting with the server account is a breeze; just insert the secret key!

With this, your files will be saved on a remote server and all product and catalog images will be synced directly with Amazon S3.

The digital age has transformed the way we store and access information. As the demand for faster and more efficient hosting services increases, cloud-based solutions like AWS have become increasingly popular. Installing Magento 2 on AWS can significantly improve the performance of your website. By following the step-by-step guide on How to Install Magento 2 on AWS and How to Deploy Magento 2 on Server, you can ensure a smooth and successful installation. Whether you’re running an e-commerce store or a personal blog, AWS is a reliable and cost-effective solution to meet your hosting needs.

Please follow and like us:
Aaron Jenkins

I am Aaron Jenkins, a Magento Developer with over 12+ years of experience. I specialize in Magento 2 and I am passionate about sharing my knowledge and experience through my blog. Here, I will be sharing tutorials, tips, and best practices for all things Magento 2. Follow my blog and let’s learn and grow together.
